bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 1948

div1.p: Truby thinks that it is crucial for Hench to get access to the Wood diary and the Lazear notebook, but encourages Hench to write his book even if he cannot see these items immediately. He also understands that Hench should not let the yellow fever project get in the way of his medical research.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 1948
div1.opener:
The Sept. number of the Military Surgeon has just
arrived. The Editorial by Col Phalen is on Walter Reed
& the Hall of Fame.
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
Sept. /48
Dear Colonel Hench:-
div1.p:
Your much appreciated letter
of July 17. was here when Mrs Truby
& I returned home from the East. We
were away 3 months and had a wonderful
time. The trip did us both a lot of good
and I was astonished at the things I
could do without fatigue. Besides the
highlights of our visit in Washington &
New York, we were presented with a
new grandaughter in Maryland and I
made a special trip to my old home in
Western N.Y. The sad part of that visit was
that only a few of my old friends are
left and those that are seem crippled up just
as I am. Human flesh just is not made
to last forever!

Mrs Truby & I enjoyed our dinner togetherwith you at
The Barclay Hotel. Sorry we could not have
had a longer visit with you there. The Hall
of Fame exercises and the people I met there,
including many old friends, was a most interesting
experience.

The Reed exercises in Washington were most
impressive and your illustrated lecture
AC
Tr
2.
most carefully prepared and delivered
You have become an expert lecturer and teacher
and likewise you have mastered the Y.F.
Episode. [unclear] I could find practically
nothing in the whole lecture that was not exactly
as I have tried to pictured it. You have visualized
the scene in Cuba extremely well. We may
differ on some of the moot questions, but I hope
that when you finally, get all the material such
as Wood's diary, Carroll's papers etc. that you
will find my memory of these things quite
reliable. I doubt if Finlay's diary will be
of much help unless it contains info. re Reed's visit.

I quite agree with you therefore that
it is most important to get Wood's diary and
the Lazear note book before you publish the
your book. However, if time permits I think you
would do well to write your manuscript, leaving
out certain parts that will need revision. You
already know the facts about most of the story
and they should be recorded before you forget them.
It might also be of help to you to let Kean, Moran
and me check over the preliminary draft
and make comments. That would be a great
treat to us even if it does not help you.

I have not seen any published reports
of the Reed celebration and your lecture. It
should have been fully covered in the Military
Surgeon but was not. I received a photo of the
group on the stage from Gen Sawyer (photo 1376-88)
When your letter come I wrote for no 93 but by
that time there were none left. Can't you get
Gen Sawyer to have a full report of the Reed exercises
published?

But I have digressed from the main point
in your letter of the 17th. Of course it is
evident to all of us that you must not let
your great hobby take you away from the
extremely important work you are doing on
chronic arthritis. It is interesting to know
that you are following up such a promising
lead on rheumatoid arthritis and I do hope
you are destined to feel the thrills of victory
just as you know Walter Reed felt in Dec. 1900
when he wrote to Mrs Reed of his successful
discovery. I realize how important your
work is and anything that can present the suffering
and debility caused by those terrible rheumatic
diseases would I think be more important than
the Y.F. discovery of Reed's. I am still reading
your Rheumatism Review and have found much
in it of interest to me. I shall pass it on
to a young medical officer at the Letterman just
as I do all publications on medical subjects.

I am still getting the “Proceedings of the
Staff meetings of the Mayo Clinic” which you
so kindly sent me some yrs. ago. Too many
of them are of no interest to me, although I have
found many things of great interest, I am
I think I should stop having them sent as
someone else would get more use out of them.
Many thanks to you for the interesting things
AC
Tr
4
I have found in them. If your secretary
would phone the proper office & have my
name removed from the mailing list I will be obliged.

This is the hurricane season in Cuba and
I do hope that your small “casa” there has
been properly protected as promised by
various Cubans. Everything is manana
to them and their promises rarely
eventualize. I did enjoy meeting Dr. Nogueira
and was so glad to findthat I had obtained a
very wrong impression of him from his first
letters to me several yrs. ago. He is quite
up and doing for a Cuban. I feel that he
is very definitely wrong about the location
of the Camp Columbia Cemetery however.

I was sorry that Moran was not present
for the Reed celebration. I hope he is much
improved by this time. Hanberry looked very
well and was the big drawing card of the show.

He was one of the men I knew very well
and he did good work as a soldier. I did
not get much information from him for my book.

Col. & Mrs La Garde enjoyed meeting you at
the Reed's dinner and were greatly impressed
by your lecture.

I have been real busy since my
return and hence this belated reply to your
good letter.

closer.salute:
With all good wishes for you & Mrs Hench
Very Sincerely yours
